description: From Anglo-Norman paragone, peragone, Middle French paragon, from Italian paragone (“comparison”) or Spanish parangón, from paragonare, from Ancient Greek παρακονάω (parakonáō, “I sharpen, whet”), from παρά (pará) +‎ ἀκόνη (akónē, “whetstone”) (from Proto-Indo-European *h₂eḱ- (“sharp”)).

entries.meaning: A person of preeminent qualities, who acts as a pattern or model for others. [from 16th c.]
examples: In the novel, Constanza is a paragon of virtue who would never compromise her reputation.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A companion; a match; an equal. [16th–19th c.]
(typography, printing, dated) The size of type between great primer and double pica, standardized as 20-point. [from 18th c.]
A flawless diamond of at least 100 carats.

verbs.description: paragon (third-person singular simple present paragons, present participle paragoning, simple past and past participle paragoned)

entries.meaning: To compare; to parallel; to put in rivalry or emulation with.
To compare with; to equal; to rival.
To serve as a model for; to surpass.
To be equal; to hold comparison.
